title: Wednesday, 20th September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am

PM11:02am

So make a note of that

People looking at a rate hike here, of course

November seems to be the fav month for that

PM11:04am

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Developments last week led to a strong repricing for a rate hike in the UK, with markets
now expecting a 60% chance of a rate hike in November:
 Hawkish September minutes: “A majority of MPC members judge that, if the
economy continues to follow a path consistent with the prospect of a continued
erosion of slack and a gradual rise in underlying inflationary pressure then, with
the further lessening in the trade-off that this would imply, some withdrawal of
monetary stimulus is likely to be appropriate over the coming months in order to
return inflation sustainably to target”.
 After that, Carney confirmed that he was among the majority on the MPC
who believe some withdrawal of monetary stimulus will be needed in the coming
months, if the economy follows its current path, and that he thought that rates
may need to be adjusted in the coming months.
 Vlieghe, the most dovish member of the MPC turned hawkish: He said that
“Until recently, I thought the appropriate response of monetary policy was to be
patient, given modest growth and subdued underlying inflationary pressure. But
the evolution of the data is increasingly suggesting that we are approaching the
moment when Bank Rate may need to rise”.

PM11:04am

Sorry for the formatting

PM11:05am

This shift in tone convinces us that the BoE is set on a November hike. Our change in
view is less to do with a change in our assessment of the economy and more with a
change in our assessment of the BoE’s reaction function.
On the economy we continue to expect UK growth of 1.5% in 2017, below the BoE’s
forecast of 1.7%. Q3 growth (at 0.2%q/q) is likely to disappoint the BoE’s forecasts at
0.3%q/q. This is because according to our forecasts consumer spending may not recover
in Q3 to offset weak business investment, as the BoE expects. In our view, the inflationary
pressure on real incomes is likely to intensify and peak in H2 2017, and assuming that the
fall in savings ratio is likely to be limited from here on; we think consumption spending
should remain subdued in H2 2017.
Inflation in the past few months has surprised to the upside. One possible explanation is
that the pass- through of the sterling fall to inflation has been faster and larger than
expected. In Figure 2, we plot the residuals of the regression to estimate core goods
inflation, using lagged core import prices. These residuals have significantly picked up
since the referendum, implying that the pass-through from the fall in sterling to inflation
has been quicker and larger than expected. Moreover this could also mean that the passthrough
might fade quicker than before, i.e., the impact of the currency on inflation may
wash out in the next 12 months or so, earlier than in past episodes.

I mean, eco isn't my field, I want to emphasise, but it does feel we're getting a wee bit ahead of ourselves in assuming policy normalisation.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

BE11:08am

Actually, as if to save you from my own malformed thoughts, Natixis has just dropped into my email.

BE11:09am

There will probably be a cautious monetary policy normalisation in the United States and the euro zone, due to the fall in unemployment and the strong job creation, the slight rise in core inflation, the strong growth - which is outpacing potential growth - and the central banks’ determination to gain leeway for the future.
This normalisation will push up long-term interest rates, but we want to see whether there are mechanisms that could work in the opposite direction and keep long-term interest rates low:

11:09 am
BE11:09am

The low level of real potential growth;
The fact that core inflation - even though it is rising - remains
modest, just like expected inflation;
The ongoing increase in global liquidity and particularly in global
foreign exchange reserves (it is not only the Federal Reserve and
the ECB that are buying US and euro-zone government bonds);
The fact that risky asset prices are already high (which prevents
investors from rotating from government bonds to risky assets).

hmm

PM11:10am

I see the argument

11:10 am

So, growth's rubbish, core inflation's meet, central banks are once again loading up on forex reserves and bonds, and risk remains quite expensive so investors have no incentive to sell government bonds .......

BE11:11am

That's not a recipe for normalised policies, is it? I emphasise here that I'm not an economist, but it looks crook to me.

"We are on track to deliver our full year strategic milestones for the second year in a row. We understand the reality of our customers' lives and are creating a unified and unique offer based on their needs. We are buying as ONE and are starting to see the customer and financial benefits coming through. This is all underpinned by our IT rollout which remains on track, and efficiency benefits which continue to deliver.

"We remain confident in our ability to deliver our five year plan and in the benefits it will generate, supported by our great team of hard-working and enthusiastic colleagues."

11:16 am

BE11:20am

Let me get some sellside.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Barclays.

BE11:20am

The company already reported Q2/1H trading on August 17th, so the focus here is on profitability. While performance – especially in the UK - was encouraging, we still remain cautious on the longer-term story for reasons we have discussed previously. Ultimately, while the company did outperform already-low expectations, we still see substantial longer-term challenges as it progresses in its 5-year plan.

BE11:21am

· Retail profit: UK & Ireland retail profits of £215m were 7% ahead of company collected consensus for £201m, and France £174m came in 1.8% ahead of company collected consensus (£171m) but below our forecasts (£193m). ‘Other’ was weaker than expected, with retail profits of £78m vs. consensus £83m and Barclays £80m. All in all, total retail profits of £467m were 2.6% ahead of company consensus and 1.5% below our estimates. The beat in the UK was driven primarily by cost savings, though interest also contributed.

· Gross margin: GMs were flat yoy in 1H, in line with guidance for the full year.

· Operating margin: Margins declined from 7.6% in 1H17 to 6.7%. This was better than our projections of 5.9% as the company benefitted from greater cost savings, especially in the UK.

· Underlying PBT: Underlying PBT grew 0.9% to £440m, 3.3% ahead of consensus for £426m.

· Unified COGS: the company has achieved 16% unified COGS and is on track to deliver the 20% that they said they would do this year. However, they have reduced the unified COGS target for next year to 40% (vs. previous 55%), while maintaining the target for 90% in year 5. Although they have maintained the LT target for now, we remain somewhat skeptical on how achievable this is.

· Unified IT rollout: the company has brought forward some of its initiatives, and now plans to re-phase the rollout of its unified IT platform to start in H2 17/18 instead of FY18/19 as laid out previously.

· Full year guidance: The company said it remains comfortable with FY consensus and underlying EPS expectations (26.2p), but remains cautious on the 2H backdrop.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

And Stifel with the valuation stuff

BE11:22am

Only 10.8x P/E FY18, (c.5.5x EV/EBITDA) with c.£600m net cash, £3.4bn freehold property and pension fund surplus, the shares look good value in our opinion. Kingfisher has completed £200m share buyback already this FY. A further £200m is due next year (and cash generation should support additional cash returns beyond this ear in our opinion).

BE11:22am

Our 455p target price is based on a weighted average of our sum-of-the-parts valuation (50%), a bull-case DCF that Kingfisher achieves £400m profit uplift from the ‘ONE’ transformation programme (25%) and a bear-case DCF that assumes no profit uplift is achieved (25%). The key risks to our target price include a potential deterioration in the UK/French/Polish consumer spending environment, including a UK ‘Brexit’, sterling/euro currency fluctuations and a deterioration in the European Union trade regime. Another key risk is that the ‘ONE’ transformation programme fails to deliver the indicated £500m profit uplifts.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And Morgan Stanley, which takes to the outlook statement with a reliably sharp eye.

BE11:24am

- Perhaps the most interesting 'n ew news' today is on strategy. Under 'One Kingfisher' the company had previously set out plans to have 20% common range in place in FY 2017/18, 55% in FY 2018/19, 80% in FY 2019/20 and 90% in FY 2020/21. However, this phasing is being changed today. The target for this year remains unchanged, as does the end goal of 90% in FY 2020/21. But the targets for FY 2018/19 and FY 2019/20 are being reduced significantly (to 40% and 60% respectively). There had been some speculation in recent weeks about a slow down in the rollout of unified ranges, so we do not think this will come as a huge surprise to investors. Nevertheless, we think it will be seen as evidence that the strategy of adopting a common range of products across the group's formats (something we are deeply skeptical about) is not working as well as management once anticipated.

PM11:24am

PM11:25am

“KGF: so given consensus shouldn't change much, today's move is all about the multiple. Brings F12M cons P/E to c.13x, which is in line with the 5y average. Basically market is showing much more confidence in management to execute on ONE than they did yesterday. Think it's still way too premature for that. Can't deny they've done ok in H1; but they've also hit unforeseen issues - at least some of which they should arguably have foreseen... So 2-3 years left to deliver the bulk of the £500m target is still a lot to ask for/believe in. Especially with changing (increasingly tough) UK landscape as backdrop. Painful today, and may continue for a bit, as it did through April/May. But still based on hope more than evidence.

PM11:33am

Spending its way to thrive in a digital world

As Diageo set out in its capital markets day, it is introducing a number of resources focused on digital insights. While these systems do not come cheap, Diageo believes it will drive greater efficiencies in key areas such as net revenue management, which may help ensure smarter, more effective trade promotion as it rolls out in the near future. As consumers shop online, the distinctions between marketing and sales divisions are becoming increasingly blurry. For example, Diageo are seeking to improve the number of 'shoppable' click-to-purchase ads, which only represents 3-4% of current ads. England is the most penetrated market with respect to digital sales at 8%, driven by gifting and holiday occasions. Outlet data analysis led to increased spending at seasonal areas such as resorts, which identified 15,000 outlets in summer hot spots in partnership with a third party. We confirmed with investor relations that this 15,000 number was not an incremental number, but certainly some were new outlets. It remains to be seen if Diageo will be able to stem the secular pressures in categories like Vodka, Irish and American Whisk(e)ys, and single malts.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 163.00, up 5.2 (+3.30%), High: 163.00, Low: 156.90, Volume: 5.43m

BE11:45am

Otherwise .............. there's Metro.

Metro Bank PLC (MTRO:LSE): Last: 3,340, down 148 (-4.24%), High: 3,435, Low: 3,330, Volume: 138.68k
11:45 am
PM11:46am

That's a change -- Metro coming back towards earth

BE11:46am

Yup -- the challenger bank with the inexplicable valuation that can't be explained exclusively by its dog-friendly policy.

BE11:46am

Macquarie's had a look and said, "huh?"

11:46 am
BE11:47am

We view management targets for 2020 as challenging and think that growth and margins will slow as the next leg of growth is increasingly driven by expansion into less wealthy regions outside of London and the South East. Management ROE targets could prove to be unrealistic.

BE11:47am

In order to achieve its target of 14% ROE by FY20e (the 18% initial target now delayed to FY22e), Metro Bank requires a 40% loan growth CAGR in combination with improving net interest margins (2016a 230bp vs. 2020t: 300bp). This suggests growing the mortgage book from c£5bn today to £14bn (FY20e) in a price-competitive and intermediated mortgage market. This seems optimistic, considering for example Virgin Money’s experience to date. Commercial lending
would also need to grow from £3bn today to £9bn (FY20e).
Metro’s deposit funding cost is now comparable to UK high street banks but we remain unconvinced that this represents an enduring competitive advantage, as we expect challenger banks to ultimately be price-takers in the deposit market. We do not expect that Metro will relax credit underwriting standards to achieve loan growth targets, although the 85% loan to value (LTV) ratio of its new mortgage lending average is high compared to other challengers (CYBG and VM/ both average around 70%).

BE11:48am

Metro Bank’s customer proposition – stores acting as ‘points of sale’ (POS) – is counter to the trend for increased digitisation and off-branch service delivery. Our proprietary survey shows customers visit banks mostly to open accounts and do business banking – here Metro remains well positioned. However, we argue that although this is positive for customer and deposit growth, delivering loan growth will need Metro to tap into the price-sensitive intermediated market.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

We estimate FY20e ROE of c12% (assuming no further equity raise) on our current estimates vs. management’s guidance of 14%. Metro raised £280m of new equity in July to pursue growth, which deferred the 18% initial ROE targets by two years to 2022. There is a risk that Metro will likely tap the market again post FY18 (as CET1 levels fall below the 11% in our current estimates) to achieve loan growth targets, likely delaying ROE delivery and further reduce Fair Values. MREL (bail-in able debt) requirements could also prove a headwind.

BE11:49am

When we look at valuation, we scenario test the 2020e financial targets – this gives us an undiscounted valuation of £24 per share. The move to IRB capital base delivers a further £3 per share delivering a FV of £27. Residual income valuation over credit cycles delivers a lower valuation of c£16 per share. Benchmarked to UK banks, Metro’s current valuation only normalises to sector averages for FY20e loans, deposits and customers. Macquarie’s proprietary quant model delivers a fourth quartile ranking in the global banks universe and with unsupportive valuation, we initiate with an Underperform rating.

PM11:49am

That's pretty comprehensive

BE11:59am

Actually, not Peel Hunt. Here's Panmure Gordon.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

CCT reasonably concludes that it does “not currently have reliable visibility on the important 2017 Christmas trading period and its effect” on FY18. We believe that the $3bn debtor-in-possession financing afforded to Toys "R" Us on Monday should eliminate collections risk for its toy suppliers. However, we recognise that CCT’s exposure is mainly to Toys “R” Us UK (which is not included in the bankruptcy protection) such that if credit insurance was completely withdrawn, then CCT would likely redirect uninsured Toys “R” Us-bound orders to other toy market retail operators. Such a scenario could potentially have an impact on our unchanged FY18 £14.5m PBT estimate, although we note our FY19 £15.5m PBT forecast has been convincingly further underpinned recently by a significant strengthening of CCT’s toy portfolio (e.g. Teletubbies’ licence extension, new Pokemon distributorship).

BE12:00pm

Toys “R” Us is not indicative of the toy industry’s decline – Investors should recall that the global toy industry has been growing at a low- to mid- single digit rate consistently over the past decade or so, and therefore remains in good health. Having said that, similar to other consumer product categories, the toy industry is rapidly evolving, with new small entrants, a strong resurgence in traditional games, digital game formats, and a pronounced distribution channel shift to online etc. We think therefore that Toys "R" Us is a "leveraged buyouts can kill companies" story rather than “another death of store-based retailing” story. Having said that, we would expect that toy suppliers, including CCT, will rationally cut back their exposure to Toys "R" Us in the coming months, not least as we can imagine that Toys "R" Us will likely go through some form of store rationalisation programme.

BE12:00pm

They're knife catching.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We are reminded that CCT had net cash of £6.9m at the end of FY16, £18.6m at H1FY17 (recalling that H1 typically sees a post Xmas seasonal peak in the annual net cash position), and we are forecasting c£14m at the end of FY17. We are also comforted that none of CCT’s financing arrangements (such as bank overdrafts, finance advances, import loans) are entangled with the Toys “R” Us bankruptcy risk. Finally, we recall that CCT successfully weathered the collapse of Woolworths (which, similarly to Toys “R” Us today, was one of CCT’s top four UK retailers at the time) in late 2008 where we understand CCT lost c£2m.

BE12:01pm

Any stockmarket-reaction-driven weakness in CCT.L is a buying opportunity – We remain fully alert to the risk of Toys “R” Us’ financially precarious situation worsening with some speed. However, on balance, our experience is that retail bankruptcies play out over time which we acknowledge can lead to a fundamental and psychological overhang for some months, such that any immediate negative pronounced share price response should be seen as a buying opportunity, in our view.
